processedVideos.transcriptText:
The double outer heart shaped swing is the perfect exercise with Indian clubs to open up the chest, lengthen the back and mobilize the shoulders.

This Indian club exercise is also great for cognitive function! By crossing the midline with both hands, your brain starts synchronizing both hemispheres. This calms the nervous system, priming it to learn new skills and make better decisions.

If you only learn one exercise with Indian clubs, make it this one!

One minute at an average pace represents about 25-30 reps. Aim for 100 repetitions a day.

Focus on smooth and rhythmic revolutions instead of how heavy you can swing.

What can Indian clubs do for you?

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

double outer heart shape swing both arms move at the same time and speed the clubs swing away from each other above the head and meet again at the legs arms cross around waist level open your elbows to the side launch the clubs as high as possible alternate hands left over right right over left etc stand tall and do not bend forward to help you use the four count swing go slow and mark each position as you improve avoid contact with the shoulders remember to alternate the crossover on each rep remember your breathing [Music] bye

# [Indian clubs 102 Lesson 13/20:  double outer heart shaped swing](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JB6fUPZENjk)

**Visibility**: Public
**Uploaded by**: [Heroic Sport - Indian clubs workouts](http://www.youtube.com/@HeroicSport)
**Uploaded at**: 2021-10-08T10:30:01-07:00
**Published at**: 2021-10-08T10:30:01-07:00
**Length**: 03:14
**Views**: 2549
**Likes**: 91
**Category**: Sports

## Description

```
The double outer heart shaped swing is the perfect exercise with Indian clubs to open up the chest, lengthen the back and mobilize the shoulders. 
This Indian club exercise is also great for cognitive function! By crossing the midline with both hands, your brain starts synchronizing both hemispheres. This calms the nervous system, priming it to learn new skills and make better decisions.
If you only learn one exercise with Indian clubs, make it this one!
One minute at an average pace represents about 25-30 reps. Aim for 100 repetitions a day. 
Starting weight for ladies: 500-750g per club
Starting weight for men: 1-1,2kg per club
Focus on smooth and rhythmic revolutions instead of how heavy you can swing.
------
What can Indian clubs do for you?
Watch this: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ft-FL_6s_No

❂ Physical benefits
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

❂ Mental benefits
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ Heroic Sport | An ancient discipline 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ range to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors and wrestlers. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
```

## Transcript

double outer heart shape swing both arms move at the same time and speed the clubs swing away from each other above the head and meet again at the legs arms cross around waist level open your elbows to the side launch the clubs as high as possible alternate hands left over right right over left etc stand tall and do not bend forward to help you use the four count swing go slow and mark each position as you improve avoid contact with the shoulders remember to alternate the crossover on each rep remember your breathing [Music] bye

parallel swing both clubs swing around in the same direction both arms move at the same time and speed they never cross going left the left arm does an outer swing the right arm and inner swing going right the right arm does an outer swing the left arm and inner swing together these make parallel swings stand tall and do not Bend forward to help you use the four count swing go slow and Mark each position as you improve avoid contact with the shoulders rotate the body while the clubs fall behind you and in front of you always practice both directions remember your breathing

inner to Outer switch wrist switch to switch Direction we use a wrist Circle perform an inner swing when the club floats above the shoulder level switch to the ring grip and do a wrist Circle let the arm fall and flow into an outer swing to help you use the four count swing go slow and Mark each position one inner swing and freeze arm to the side above the shoulder Club lined up two wrist Circle to order three Club an arm lined up four arm swings down to Outer swing try to keep the arm straight with light clubs with heavy clubs Bend the arm to assist the momentum

processedVideos.transcriptText:
Thierry takes you through the steps to perform an overhead squat with 2 light Indian clubs in full flow.

If you do not master the heart shaped swings, you can substitute full arm circles instead.

When you understand the timing of the swing, you'll also be able to swing in the reverse direction, and substitute squats for different types of lunges.

Foundational movements allow you to build up your repertoire of skills by adding variations, or layers, to a basic pattern.

Maintain your back as vertical as possible as you descend into the squat, to allow the clubs to properly swing in the right planes behind your back.

The squat is demonstrated with weight on the toes, as a Hindu squat or Hack squat, but it can also be done with heels in the ground if you have the required mobility to maintain a vertical back.

Only attempts this exercise if you do not have any knee problems.

WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS

Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion

Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion

Consists of compound movements in multiple planes

Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise

Assists recovery from intense training

Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)

It is fun and you forget you are training.

The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.

Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT

Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors.

Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.

outer swing with a squat stand with the feet close together at 45 degrees start with an outer heart-shaped swing lower yourself into a squat onto your toes after the hands cross at the front of the body proper timing is essential the clubs turned behind the back on the descent the arms must be straight in the bottom position stand up as soon as the clubs start falling out to the sides stay as upright as possible in the bottom position remember to alternate the crossing hand each repetition do not attempt if you have knee pain you

# [Indian clubs 102 Lesson 20/20: Heart shaped swings with an overhead squat](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OCds7XhCXeQ)

**Visibility**: Public
**Uploaded by**: [Heroic Sport - Indian clubs workouts](http://www.youtube.com/@HeroicSport)
**Uploaded at**: 2021-03-12T00:30:12-08:00
**Published at**: 2021-03-12T00:30:12-08:00
**Length**: 03:10
**Views**: 1371
**Likes**: 60
**Category**: Sports

## Description

```
Thierry takes you through the steps to perform an overhead squat with 2 light Indian clubs in full flow. 
If you do not master the heart shaped swings, you can substitute full arm circles instead.

When you understand the timing of the swing, you'll also be able to swing in the reverse direction, and substitute squats for different types of lunges. 
Foundational movements allow you to build up your repertoire of skills by adding variations, or layers, to a basic pattern.

Maintain your back as vertical as possible as you descend into the squat, to allow the clubs to properly swing in the right planes behind your back.

The squat is demonstrated with weight on the toes, as a Hindu squat or Hack squat, but it can also be done with heels in the ground if you have the required mobility to maintain a vertical back.
Only attempts this exercise if you do not have any knee problems. 


WHY YOU SHOULD SWING INDIAN CLUBS
〄 PHYSICAL ASPECTS
Gently mobilizes the shoulders, elbows and wrists and improve range of motion
Strengthens the shoulder girdle and grip ( muscles and connective tissues) in its full range of motion
Consists of compound movements in multiple planes
Provides low impact cardiovascular exercise
Assists recovery from intense training
Improves the 3 pillars of physical literacy (body control , locomotion and object control)
〄 MENTAL ASPECTS
It is fun and you forget you are training.
The rhythmic and repetitive patterns are highly meditative and calm the nervous system, like meditation.
Cross crawl exercises and other challenging moves improve learning capacity and stimulate neurogenesis, the creation of new brain cells.

❂ HEROIC SPORT | AN ANCIENT SPORT 
We have created the Pahlavandle ™ and the Pahlavandle™XL to make it affordable for everyone to discover the benefits of swinging clubs.
Our clubs are easily adjustable, which is a modern twist on the ancient traditional Indian clubs used to train Tamil and Persian warriors. 
Indian clubs were used in Europe and USA for remedial gymnastics in the 18th and 19th century, by pioneers of physiotherapy.
```

## Transcript

outer swing with a squat stand with the feet close together at 45 degrees start with an outer heart-shaped swing lower yourself into a squat onto your toes after the hands cross at the front of the body proper timing is essential the clubs turned behind the back on the descent the arms must be straight in the bottom position stand up as soon as the clubs start falling out to the sides stay as upright as possible in the bottom position remember to alternate the crossing hand each repetition do not attempt if you have knee pain you

processedVideos.transcriptText:
Indian clubs are a great tool to challenge the vestibular system while you're getting a full body workout.

Persian warriors had to face multiple opponents on the battle fields and stay focused in the heat of battle.

You can chose to look straight ahead or use the body in a more optimal way, by turning the head allowing for natural rotation.

At www.heroicsport.com we have created the Pahlavandle, a pair of handles that fit on PET bottles to create adjustable Indian clubs up to 3kg. We also teach you how to swing Indian clubs and provide lots of inspiration on how to include them in your training.

hey Terry from her exporters and me'll turns like this looking at the camera make sure they look good for Instagram I mean it's okay you know you can do that when you're proficient when you learn all you want to challenge your vegetable system you should be doing this kind of stuff right so as you cast the club you look at the end of it traditionally the meals got some stripes to provide visual reference yeah turn and swing and pull down so you're gonna remember that the the meal were used to Train warriors for the battlefields multiple opponents you know they have to look around and and not get dizzy and make sure don't whack the wrong guys so I apply this concept next time you're swinging evening clubs you know you don't just reach across like this but the head follow the head leads and the body follows this allows for a more natural and free rotation from the news hips spine and everything so apply this concept next time you swim in the clubs
